findings.title: Misleading Skill Package - Not an Agent Skill
findings.description: This package is advertised as an agent skill but is actually an NPM package (npx ai-diff-summary) that requires external installation and execution. The SKILL.md contains no agent instructions, only documentation for a standalone CLI tool. This is deceptive packaging that misleads users about the skill's nature and functionality.
findings.snippet: Quick Start section shows 'npx ai-diff-summary' - this is an NPM package installation command, not agent skill usage. No agent instructions like 'When the user asks to...' are present.
findings.remediation: Either: (1) Convert to proper agent skill format with agent instructions and bundled scripts, or (2) Clearly label as external tool documentation, not an agent skill package.

metadata.overall_assessment: This package has MEDIUM severity security concerns. The primary issue is that it's not actually an agent skill - it's documentation for an external NPM CLI tool (npx ai-diff-summary) masquerading as an agent skill package. The SKILL.md contains no agent instructions, only CLI usage documentation. Additionally, it requires an OPENAI_API_KEY without security guidance, references a missing main.py file, and lacks proper metadata. The package appears to be either incorrectly packaged or intentionally deceptive. It should either be converted to a proper agent skill with bundled scripts and agent instructions, or clearly labeled as external tool documentation.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The evidence is unambiguous: every usage example is an NPM command (npx ai-diff-summary), there are zero agent instructions, and the package references a missing main.py file while showing Node.js commands. This is definitively not an agent skill.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Users may unknowingly install and execute external NPM packages they didn't intend to run, potentially exposing their system to supply chain attacks
metadata.meta_impact: High - Users expect a sandboxed agent skill but instead get instructions to install external software with full system access. The external package requires OPENAI_API_KEY which could be exfiltrated.

findings.title: External API Key Requirement - Credential Exposure Risk
findings.description: The skill requires OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable but provides no guidance on secure handling. Users may expose their API keys through environment variables that could be accessed by other processes or logged. The skill does not specify how the key is used or transmitted.
findings.snippet: 'OPENAI_API_KEY required' - No security guidance provided for API key handling, storage, or transmission.
findings.remediation: Add explicit security guidance: (1) How the API key is used, (2) Whether it's transmitted externally, (3) Secure storage recommendations, (4) Scope of API access required.

The package appears to be either incorrectly packaged or intentionally deceptive. metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The requirement for OPENAI_API_KEY is explicit, and the external nature of the NPM package means users cannot verify its behavior without manually inspecting the GitHub repository.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Requires user to have an OpenAI API key and follow the installation instructions
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - API key exposure could lead to unauthorized API usage charges or data exfiltration through API calls

findings.title: Missing Script Implementation - Broken Functionality
findings.description: The instructions reference 'main.py' as a script file, but this file is not found in the package. This indicates either incomplete packaging or a tool shadowing attempt where the actual implementation is hidden or replaced by the external NPM package.
findings.snippet: Referenced file 'main.py' not found in package. Instructions show NPX commands instead of Python execution.
findings.remediation: Include all referenced script files in the package, or remove references to missing files. Ensure package is complete and self-contained.

metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The file listing explicitly shows main.py is referenced but not present. This is a factual packaging error.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Low - This is a packaging error, not an active exploit
metadata.meta_impact: Low - Causes confusion but no direct security harm. May indicate rushed or careless packaging.
